basics.name: Stephen Bunn
basics.label: Software Engineer
basics.summary: Highly driven engineer passionate about simple and sustainable software development. Experience with backend system engineering, web development, and team leadership. Seeking a fulfilling role with a group of dedicated people where our work with modern technology can be impactful.

work.name: Capital One
work.summary: Working with the Cloud Productivity Engineering group to better Capital One's goal of operating fully on the cloud.

work.name: Grove Collaborative
work.summary: Acted as the team lead of the Growth and Web engineering teams. Planned and oversaw technical improvements to Grove's web client.
highlights: Led the design and development of a web component library. This library was engineered to meet accessibility guidelines and be extensible in any Vue-based rendering environment (SPA, SSR, static page generation).
Improved both site performance and SEO by transitioning most all landing pages to auto-generated static pages.
Key contributor in addressing web accessibility concerns and in creating guidelines for producing accessible features in the future.
Directly responsible SME in Grove's frontend guild helping to define and estimate North Stars for frontend-minded teams.
Facilitated continuous communication between stakeholders in marketing, design, analytics, and other engineering teams.

work.name: Grove Collaborative
work.summary: Worked on a special-ops engineering team focused on solving complex business requirements and investigating technical issues.
highlights: Helped to implement payment method fraud detection. Integrated with several third-party services to handle capturing payment from customers on first-time checkouts.
Constructed CMS content schemas and produced reusable presentational components to allow content managers to construct and publish web pages.
Helped to establish effective code quality tooling and style guides throughout the engineering organization.

work.name: Sensus
work.summary: Worked on a small team of engineers focused on building the platform and standards for creating customer-facing applications.
highlights: Built and maintained the customer experience development platform used to consolidate user authentication, product management, and the return process for customers.
Assisted in developing tooling to aggregate internal analytics and telemetry that Sensus uses to monitor the performance of most areas of the business.

work.name: Appalachian State University
work.position: Web Content Manager, Office of Sustainability
work.summary: Primary content manager of the front-end of the sustain subdomain at appstate.edu. Maintained the Office of Sustainability's Google presence.

work.name: Appalachian State University
work.position: Graduate Student Researcher, Department of Computer Science
work.summary: Performed research in the optimization of existing package management systems in the component, module, and software levels of package management.

work.name: East Carolina University
work.position: NSF REU Researcher, Department of Computer Science
work.summary: Performed research in both production level testing methods and the use of sentiment analysis in data mining. Specifically perfomed sentiment analysis on textual data taken from online resources such as Twitter, Facebook, and YouTube.

work.name: North Carolina Department of Transportation
work.summary: Imaged and distributed statewide computer systems for the NC Division of Motor Vehicles. Helped with the implementation of a new security protocol for the Triangle Transportation Management Center.

work.name: Carney & Co
work.summary: Managed the upkeep of several simple file servers. Provided customer service to clients. Contributed research for several marketing and political projects, including a statewide homeschool convention and a North Carolina House of Representative candidate's campaign.

courses: CS5110 - Design and Analysis of Algorithms

awards.title: SSTEM Scholarship Recipient
awards.summary: Awarded the SSTEM scholarship due to great performance in his studies.

publications.name: Applying Package Management To Mod Installation
publications.summary: Package management automates the discovery and installation of software that can coexist within an operating system. The methods used by package management can also address other instances where the installation of software needs to be automated. One example of this is the environment produced by third party video game modifications. An adapted application of package management practices can help to solve the difficult problem of finding and installing a set of video game modifications that do not conflict with each other. This greatly benefits the environment by allowing third party contributions to be easily installed which fosters growth in both the developer and user community surrounding the environment. This thesis presents the theory and complexities behind package management and shows how it can be effectively applied to managing video game modifications by presenting examples of software that can extract relevant metadata from video game modifications and discover conflict free installation solutions.
